section.title: Overview
section.para: The Hotelling feature provides for defining a set of 'hotel' phones whose features and lines are temporarily reconfigured for a user when that user 'signs in' to the phone. The reconfiguration is reversed either when the user explicitly 'signs out' or after some system-configured elapsed time.

The motivation for this feature is to support environments in which some users are mobile, so a larger population of users can be supported using a smaller number of phones, while preserving the personalization of phone settings and capabilities specific for each user.

section.title: Typical User Scenario
section.para: The following scenario illustrates how the hotelling feature is used. This section is intended only as an example; it is not intended to show all aspects of the Hotelling feature set. Subsequent sections more fully define the requirements.

Our example scenario takes place in an office of JumboExample Corp (a member of the Example family of companies). JumboExample has many field operatives that spend most of thier time away from the office, but each has an occasional need to come in to file reports, attend staff meetings, and be briefed on changes in JumboExample policies. Joe Schmoe is one of these field operatives.

Joe arrives at the office on Monday morning, and goes to the Field Operative section, where there are 15 cubicles available for operatives when they are in the facility. Each cubicle is supplied with furniture, basic office supplies, a laptop docking station with large screen monitor, and a SIP phone.

Joe goes down the line of cubicles, past a few that are occupied by other field operatives, until he finds one that appears to be available. Before sitting down, he checks the display on the SIP phone and sees that the phone display indeed indicates that no one is presently logged in to this phone (see ).

Joe sits down, puts his laptop in the docking station and the picture of his dog on the desk, and then logs in to the phone. The phone in this cubicle is equipped with several speed dial buttons, one of which is labeled "Login". He presses this button and after one ring the call is answered by the login autoattendant. The autoattendant prompts him for his personal extension number, which he enters, and it then prompts him for his PIN (this is the same PIN he uses for voicemail), which he also enters. After a brief pause, the autoattendant confirms that his login is successful and instructs him to hang up the phone and wait for it to be reconfigured. Joe hangs up and goes to get coffee (and to see if anyone has left unwanted sweets at the coffee station).

A moment after Joe leaves the cubicle, the phone reboots (see ). When he returns, the first line on the phone is displaying that it is now his extension number, and the message waiting dispay indicates that he has 2 new voicemail messages.

Joe presses the 'Messages' key on the phone to connect to his mailbox, enters his PIN, and deals with the messages. Then he uses the first speed dial key, which is now programmed to the number for the administrative assistant for his team. The assistant answers and preempts his question about where the staff meeting is to be held today: she knew from her caller-id display that it was Joe, and he always calls to ask. Other speed dial keys on the phone are programmed for his home number and that of his supervisor.

While he is reading his email, his supervisor calls: to call him, she had just dialled his extension number, not needing to know which cubicle he had selected. She wants him to meet with her at the end of the day to go over sales projections in his area for the coming month.

Before leaving at the end of the day, Joe repacks his laptop and photo, and presses the speed dial key that is programmed to log him out. The system answers the call and plays an acknowlegement message, but Joe is already on his way home. After a moment, the call disconnects and the phone reboots. When it comes back up, it is again displaying that it is an unassigned phone.
